titleStmt.title: Description of Bryn Mawr College Library, MS 35: De miseria conditionis humanae
titleStmt.funder: Council on Library and Information Resources

notesStmt.note: Water damage throughout; first leaf nearly detached; paper repairs to fols. 1r-2v

msContents.summary: This manuscript of the late twelfth-century text De miseria conditionis humanae was produced in Italy in the second half of the fifteenth century. The author of the work was the cardinal Lotario dei Segni, who later became Pope Innocent III. This copy is written on paper in a Gothic cursive script, with red and blue initials.

msItem.title: Prima pars
msItem.incipit: Quare de vulva matris egressus sum . . . [fol. 1r]

msItem.title: Secunda pars
msItem.explicit: ... non sumet omnia neque desendet [sic] cum eo gloria eius. [fol. 28v]

msItem.title: Tercia pars
msItem.incipit: Non est quidem corpus vel cordis munditia ... [fol. 28v]
msItem.explicit: Fulgur et ignis Ardens in secula seculorum. Amen. Deo gratias semper. Amen. [fol. 37v]

supportDesc.extent: 39+i; 215 x 160 mm bound to 220 x 165 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto

p.signatures: Leaf signatures in lower right corner of final gathering (fols. 31-35)

p.catchwords: Horizontal catchwords centered in lower margin verso

layoutDesc.layout: Single column written in thirty-four lines; single vertical bounding lines full length; first quire bounded in lead, remaining three in ink with occasional horizontal bounding lines at upper margin; written area: 138 x 91 mm

decoDesc.decoNote: Seven-line and nine-line initials in red or blue at the beginning of each part; four-line red and blue initials alternate throughout at the beginning of each chapter; faded remnants of red penwork grounds behind initials; majuscules touched with red; rubricated in red; marginalia throughout

history.provenance: Produced in Italy in the second half of the fifteenth century given the style of script and decoration; unidentified "GHo52" in ink and "H 1191" in pencil on front pastedown; unidentified "46" in ink on fol. 1r together with remnant of a round library stamp (43 mm) in lower margin with the word "Bibliotheca" recognizable below a flower; other words missing because paper substratum has been destroyed; on fol. 38v unidentified "Cart. 37" in ink; manuscript belonged to Laura Hurd Motion who gave it to Bryn Mawr College in 1980
